modules.description: These exercises apply to all speech. They are the prerequisite for tackling specific hard sounds.

exercises.title: Airflow Practice
exercises.desc: Improves breath control when starting vowel sounds
exercises.purpose: To prevent holding breath before speaking and ensure continuous air support.

steps.label: Posture
steps.text: Sit upright with shoulders relaxed.

steps.label: Inhale
steps.text: Take a deep breath into your belly (not chest). Feel your stomach expand.

steps.label: The Pre-Exhale
steps.text: Let out a tiny, silent 'sigh' of air.

steps.label: The Voice
steps.text: Ride that sigh into pronouncing the word. Do not stop the air.

instruction_set.visual_cue: [Image of diaphragm breathing vs chest breathing]

data_bank.description: Words starting with vowels, categorized by phoneme for specific selection.

exercises.title: Flexible Pacing
exercises.desc: Helps you start long words more slowly
exercises.purpose: To buy your brain time to plan motor movements by slowing the first syllable.

steps.label: Identify
steps.text: Identify the first syllable of the word.

steps.label: Stretch
steps.text: Intentionally stretch the vowel of that first syllable.

steps.label: Slide
steps.text: Slide continuously into the rest of the word without chopping it up.

data_bank.description: Multi-syllabic words with stretched first syllable.

modules.description: These exercises are for when the user is ALREADY stuck or about to be stuck.

exercises.title: Preparatory Set
exercises.desc: Plan smooth starts for feared words
exercises.purpose: To plan a fluent onset when you anticipate a stutter on a specific word.

steps.label: Pause
steps.text: Identify the word. Do not rush into the word. Stop immediately when you fear the word.

steps.label: Map
steps.text: Mentally plan to use an 'Easy Onset' (for vowels) or 'Light Contact' (for consonants).

steps.label: Action
steps.text: Say the word using the tool you planned.

data_bank.description: High-pressure words commonly associated with anticipation anxiety.

exercises.title: Pull-Out
exercises.desc: Release tension while stuck on a word
exercises.purpose: To reduce tension and release a word while you are currently stuck.

steps.label: Freeze
steps.text: Don't force it. Freeze exactly where you would stutter.

steps.label: Locate Tension
steps.text: Where is the tightness? (Throat? Lips? Tongue?). Focus on it.

steps.label: Melt & Slide
steps.text: Consciously relax that specific muscle while prolonging the sound, then slide out.

data_bank.description: Visual representations of stuttered words. User must simulate the block and pull out.

exercises.title: Block Correction
exercises.desc: Calm down and redo the word smoothly
exercises.purpose: To neutralize panic after a stutter and re-program the brain with a fluent correction.

steps.label: Stop
steps.text: Finish the word/sentence, then stop completely for 3 seconds.

steps.label: Reset
steps.text: Use this pause to neutralize the panic and calm the motor system.

steps.label: Re-do
steps.text: Say the word again, but this time use a 'Light Contact' or 'Easy Onset'.

example_demonstration.execution_text: (Pause 3 seconds). (Internal thought: Light contact on C). 'Coffee.'

data_bank.description: Sentences containing a target word to simulate a stutter on.

modules.description: This is the core feature you requested. Users select the specific sound family they are struggling with.

exercises.title: Gentle Onset
exercises.desc: Helps start vowels and M, N, L sounds gently
exercises.purpose: To prevent hard glottal attacks (vocal cords slamming shut) by initiating sound gently.

steps.label: Airflow
steps.text: Start with a gentle breath. Let the air move freely before you begin to speak.

steps.label: The Ramp
steps.text: Focus on the first letter, gradually raising your volume from 1% to 100% .

steps.label: Connection
steps.text: Do not stop the airflow between the start and the rest of the word. Blend the sound smoothly.

example_demonstration.execution_text: Hum the ‘m’ gently before opening mouth. 'Mmmmother'.

data_bank.description: Words starting with vowels and voiced liquid/nasal consonants.

exercises.title: Light Contacts
exercises.desc: Reduces tension in P, B, T, D, K, G sounds
exercises.target_group: Plosives (P, B, T, D, K, G)
exercises.purpose: To prevent lips or tongue from pressing too tightly and blocking air.

steps.label: Touch
steps.text: Bring your articulators (lips or tongue) together so lightly that they barely touch.

steps.label: Initiation
steps.text: Initiate pronouncing the word from first letter making the sound 'mushy.'

steps.label: Finish
steps.text: Don't let the air stop completely and finish the word.

example_demonstration.execution_text: Barely touch lips. Sound almost like a 'V' or 'W'. 'Bvbaby'.
Touch tongue tip feather-lightly to the roof of the mouth. 'Tthime'.
Back of tongue touches roof of mouth gently. Let air leak through. 'Khh-ite'.

exercises.title: Prolongation
exercises.desc: Keeps airflow steady in S, F, SH, TH sounds
exercises.purpose: To maintain flowing air through sounds where stutterers often hold their breath.

steps.label: Identify
steps.text: Prepare yourself to read the word in a single breath focusing on the first letter.

steps.label: Slide
steps.text: Start the first letter and slide physically into the vowel without taking a pause between letters.

example_demonstration.execution_text: 'Ssssssnake' (Do not pause between S and n).

modules.description: Playful, low-pressure exercises designed to build fluency, confidence, and spontaneous speech through engagement rather than correction.

exercises.title: Tongue Twisters
exercises.desc: Improves clarity in hard sound clusters
exercises.purpose: To improve articulatory control while maintaining airflow and reducing fear of difficult sound sequences.

steps.label: Preview
steps.text: Read the tongue twister silently and identify tricky sound clusters.

steps.label: Slow Initiation
steps.text: Begin speaking slowly with steady airflow.

steps.label: Connected Speech
steps.text: Repeat again, keeping sounds connected without stopping airflow.

instruction_set.visual_cue: Wave or dot-based pacing under each word.

example_demonstration.target_phrase: She sells seashells by the seashore
example_demonstration.execution_text: Maintain airflow and let mistakes pass without restarting.

data_bank.description: Tongue twisters grouped by dominant sound focus.

S: She sells seashells by the seashore
Six slippery snails slid slowly seaward
B: Big black bugs bleed blue blood

exercises.title: Video Diary
exercises.desc: Builds confidence in everyday speaking situations
exercises.purpose: To build comfort with spontaneous speech and reduce anxiety around being heard or seen.

steps.label: Prompt
steps.text: Read the prompt and take a moment to think.

steps.label: Record
steps.text: Speak naturally. Pauses are allowed.

steps.label: Reflect
steps.text: Replay only if you want to.

instruction_set.visual_cue: Soft countdown timer with no error indicators.

example_demonstration.target_prompt: Describe something that made you smile today.

data_bank.description: Open-ended prompts encouraging natural, unscripted speech.

daily_life: Describe a small moment you noticed
opinions: Talk about a movie or show you like
Talk about a song you love
reflection: What are you looking forward to?

exercises.title: Story Cubes
exercises.desc: Improves fluent speaking while thinking quickly
exercises.purpose: To practice fluent speech while thinking on the spot, similar to real-life conversations.

steps.label: Reveal Cues
steps.text: Look at the randomly generated story cues.

steps.label: Begin Story
steps.text: Start speaking and build a story using the cues.

steps.label: Continue Flow
steps.text: If you pause or stumble, continue without restarting.

instruction_set.visual_cue: Floating cue cards with gentle animations.

example_demonstration.execution_text: Focus on flow, not perfect storytelling.

data_bank.description: Randomized cues grouped by type to vary cognitive demand.
